comments.commentBody: Denny's didn't happen that long ago!

JB, "chaotic jumble" is the mot juste in describing THURXWDP!

WHH

In England, when I was a student, we used to sing " it's the rich that gets the gravy, it's the poor that gets the blame, it's the same the whole world over, ain't it a bloody shame "

Society to survive has to nurture everyone, bring us together to live in peace, harmony and with a measure of affluence.
It is ironic that the "have nots" (revolutionaries?) want a system that gives them control of the spoils. The rich has a system which allow them to plunder and complain about monies being spent on less fortunate humans. Unfortunately, as history shows, this is a normal human condition, greed and selfishness will win... Do we humans have a future?

Professor Krugman please keep speaking out... You cannot "save the world " (some famous economists have already done that for tthe greedy) but you can help people understand that there could be a path a a better place for all of us!

Geoffrey Brooks

Unfortunately the world is owned and run by people who believe the purpose of an economy is to endlessly concentrate wealth in the hands of fewer and fewer people. They are going to take us for all we're worth, which is not much. But they want it all, every last crumb.

The next bubble is already built. According to the financial crooks= goldman sachs - derivatives in play now are 6-7 times what they were in 2007 when the market crashed- their estimate over a QUADZILLION enough to sink nearly all western economies.

5+ years and still our inept and colluding congress has done NOTHING to re-regulate the financial crooksters. Dodd-Frank is so watered down it is useless. What makes sense is a re-instatement of Glass-Steagall and more-

The banks need to be broken up with a re-instatement of Glass-Steagall and banning of naked shorts (including shorting clients stock holdings) on basic materials, commodities, precious metals, food and water and an open transparent market for derivatives. Implement a transaction tax on all trades and a surcharge on all financial industry pay above $500,000 including bonuses, all funds collected to be directed SOLELY at paying off the federal government debt. And pass new laws mandating treble damages and criminal jail time for convicted financial crooksters along with confiscation of their worldly wealth.

Let me suggest we need a brand new "Committee to Save the World", led by economists like PK, Joseph Stiglitz, and James Galbraith, and a few others who understand that the purpose of an economy is not to endlessly concentrate wealth in the hands of fewer and fewer people. That end cannot be accomplished without meaningful regulation of financial markets, and international agreements to prevent entire national economies being taken down by a bunch of highly leveraged currency speculators, derivative cowboys, and the occasional London Whale.

The last thing we need is another set of asset bubbles, induced by Wall Street enablers, austerians, and anti-tax, anti-government cultists looking to further rig the US and global economy on behalf of the billionaires. We need an economy that creates millions of new living-wage jobs instead of a few more untaxed billionaires hiding money in their foreign bank accounts.

This is a beautiful article. Sometimes parents don't want contact with their children. So sad to be on the receiving end and come to terms with it. How wonderful that the author's father chose to spend his life with a loving family.

Paulson former ceo of goldman sachs and then sec. of the treasury...one of the the three amigos= paulson, bernacke and geithner chose who was to fail and who was to win and the winners inherited the losers for pennies on the dollar. PLUS=

The three amigos made goldman sachs a bank magically over night so they could slip the head of wall street crooks approx. $40 BILLION in taxpayer bailout money and then they stuck AIG with over $100 BILLION in goldman sachs losses and then bailed out aig to the tune of over $150 BILLION....

Now five plus years later and not one significant indictment of the wall street crooks and not one has missed a paycheck or bonus while tens of millions of Americans have lost their jobs and/or homes....

And the too big to fail are much, much larger now.....and still they are not regulated and neither are toxic derivatives. According to goldman sachs derivatives in play now are 5-6 times as much in value as they were when the bubble burst in 2007= over $1.2 QUADZILLION more money than in all of the world by about 60 times.

America No Longer The Land Of The Free and No Longer The Land Of The Beautiful.

While the article does not say it, as the condo still exists I imagine the Treasury seized and sold it to recover the money, as such the TARP funds were repaid and we the people were not ultimately stolen from.
And racial discrimation against employees based on the customers’ prejudice is absolutely illegal.  That defense doesn’t fly.

$160 million is hardly a big payout and given its history, ML seems to have the contigency funds in place for such legal matters.  My sense is that they actually executed their risk managment plan in settling for such a small payout.
the hedges have termites and rot. they need to be cut down.
And discriminating against employees based on the customers’ prejudice is absolutely illegal.  That defense won’t fly.
Unfortunately racism is alive and well in pro sports too.  Remember when there hardly any black quarterbacks?

Joe, compliments from a white girl for the thought but lets if we go to the genotype–phenotype relationship things started to change lately. The genotype integrates elements of phenotype if they stay constant from one generation to another. I speak from experience?
At the opposite side of the spectrum is the example of the white woman as a suicide bomber....

paulson one of the three amigos who sold American taxpayers down the road and rewarded the bank crooks with bailouts and a window to pay back the gov loans at near zero interest.

All three should be indicted- berancke, paulson and geithner along with the heads of nearly every major bank.

5+ years and still the banks are unregulated ala Glass-Steagall and the very same toxic derivatives are still not regulated.

America no longer the Land Of The Free and No Longer The Beautiful!

I'm nearing the end of my final two-year contract with Verizon Wireless (I've been with them for 18 years.) This time around I'll lose my unlimited data plan if I buy a subsidized phone through them, or else I can keep unlimited by paying $600 for a phone outright. Without that unlimited data there's no reason for me to stay with Verizon Wireless anymore. That unlimited data plan kept me happily locked into Verizon every two years, now, not so much. If I'm going to lose unlimited anyway, AT&T seems to offer more phones, T-Mobile and Sprint seem to offer better plans. I doubt I'm the only one who will be looking outside Verizon now. Stockholders beware.
A virtual roadmap for the next freeze, so that it's only a matter of when?

Steve, I ask you do not forget that you have in the US also a few places which could be seen as tax havens. Have a look in Florida who have bank accounts there. The mexican government tries since years to get information about money from drug dealers or people which would like to avoid taxes. This is a global problem which should be solved globally. Otherwise it has always this bad taste of a financial war.

Somewhere m where on the web, I read that there are about 32 Trillion $$ in tax havens, I presume this is not just USA residents. But think of all the tricks played by lawyers re eg the enormous oil busness

Romney and his pals tax havens in the carribean had better look out. NOt only has he exported millions of jobs to places like commie china etc, but he never released his tax statements until he amended them, and thats probably the tip of the iceberg.

I've met the Patriarch folks and I could not have less respect for them.  Ms. Tilton is flashy, brash and foolish.  Women should certainly have a greater role in business but not in the self-aggrandizing and insecure way she approaches things.  When I spoke with Ms. Tilton and her team, I simply couldn't take them seriously.  This story does not surprise me.  Patriarch doesn't save ailing businesses, it just buys them and packages them into ill-performing structured vehicles.  Her team is a motley crew of B and C players, and after all the Zohar CLOs pay off or default, she will likely not have much of a business remaining.
Of course this is on the up and up. I can't imagine there's even the appearance of any impropriety. Who could?

I'm in shock.  How could the government think for one minute that a quid pro quo, or a wink, or even a tiny little nod, might have existed.  The American people deserve to believe we have clean government!  How could the government itself take actions that might undercut our faith!
Congress, more specifically, Senate chamber, please confirm the FCC chair so that the telecom industry can start hiring again.

A slap on the wrist.
Even in the justice system it's socialism for the rich and capitalism for everyone else.

You're 100% correct - the City has stricter caps on companies (and their employees) that seek to do business with NYC and its agencies, and the SEC only lets hedge fund employees donate a maximum of $350 (and that's only if you live in New York City - $150 if you don't). This reporter failed to make a simple phone call to a campaign finance lawyer or even read (or at least comprehend) countless other articles that talk about pay-to-play.

And Mr. Chanos, it’s *not* hard to think how any hedge fund would directly benefit from city politics -- or are you saying hudge funds aren't interested in managing NYCERS $40+ billion in assets?

This was how Andrew Cuomo got his "consulting" job with Andrew Farkas. Cuomo let Farkas off after he stole millions from HUD. Farkas paid Cuomo $3 million!

As detailed in this article: http://www.dunwalke.com/sidebars/andrew_cuomo.htm
